addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

15 Martij
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./. from the Hagh.
To have direction for his proceedinge w
th
e
Empero
rs
Commissoner.
/

page.lettertext:
fol.162r
May it please yo
r
good L. Understanding
by yo
r
letter of
e 24 of
e last, howe her
Ma
tie
is affected in those affaires of importance, w
ch
I had proposed, I will doe my best endevo
r
, to
that effect as yo
r
L. hath signified her pleasure
I have commoned often sins w
t
e Emperors
Ambassado
r
, but there hath nothing passed, that
was of any moment, more then that whiche yo
r
L. hath knowen by my former. Onely this he
would seeme to say upon knowledge, and doth
protest it unto me w
t
a solemne assertion,
at
there is no suche intelligence, nor inwardnes,
between
e Empero
r
and
e
K. of Spaine
, as
most men doe imagine, but rather many cros-
singes and secret dislikes, and
at at this p
nt
,
and in these very actions, wherein
e king is
nowe buisied in
France
and els where. By
all his talke in this respect, and in
e opinion
heere of divers of special experience, there is
some cause to conjecture,
at
e Spanishe kinge
hath no intention, to give his
daughter
to the
Empero
r
, but doth feede him a farre w
t
some
hope in
at behalf, to use him onely as a
meanes for
e reducing of these contreis, to his
owne obedience: and
at
e Empero
r
on
e
other side hath no care to conclude a general
Accord, but in hope to have his daughter in
mariage, and these contreis in dowairie. The
rather, for
at
e daughter hath right of inheri
tance to
e Duchie of
Brabant,
as
e eldest
of her father. Wherupon it is supposed,
at all
fol.162v
this practise for a Peace, will quaile upon
e sod-
daine. I doe finde
at this Ambassa-
do
r
, upon
e talke
at he hath had w
t
divers men
heere, is wholy out of hope to obtene his purpose
of
e states, unles
England
and France be delt
w
t
all first. For w
ch
he is resolved to persuade
w
t
e Emperor, to take an other course, and to
send directly to her Ma
tie
. He hath made ma-
ny motives about it, in his conference w
t
me,
and hath urged me to knowe my opinion and li-
king, howe I thought
at suche a message would
be welcome to her Ma
tie
. But I have al-
aies made him but a sparing answear, That
e Treaty of
e Spaniard in
e yere Eightieight
was so full of fraude and dishono
r
, and all his
former dealinges w
t
e people of this contrey so
treacherous and injust, as her Hig
nes
had good
cause, to reject all
e Treaties,
at were offered
directly or indirectly from him. Nevertheles
because I was assured of her naturall incli-
nation to
e embracing of Peace, I made no
doubt unto my self, but
at her Hig
nes
of her
princely custome, if any suche Ambassado
r
were
sent unto her, would both receave him with
honor, and shewe him favo
r
and respect in
e
audience of his message, as
e mater shall re-
quire. I have used no other speeches, to draw
him onward in his purpose, not knowing howe
her Ma
tie
might like of my doinges. But if I
may have any notice,
at her Hig
nes
can be plea-
sed, for
e better intertening of these offers of
fol.163r
Peace,
at
e Empero
r
should be wrought to ad-
dresse an Ambassade unto her, I will as of my
self, and in
e way of communication, wherto I
can finde many fitte opportunities, confirme
this Ambassado
r
in his forsaid intention.
There is no assemblie yet begonne of
e
General
states
, through
e absence of one of
e Deputies
of
Zeland,
who they say notw
t
standing will be
heere as to day. Otherwise I thinke
e rest
at
are come, will meete in suche nomber as
ei are,
and graunt accesse unto
e Ambassado
r
, who com-
plaineth exceedingly of their odious delayes.
The
Frenche Kinge
in a letter of
e 13 of this
moneth, after their account, hath written thankes
unto
e states, for
e Loane of those souldiers, w
ch
they sent him of late, w
t
a further suite unto them,
to have them there continued, as long as
Rouen
is
besieged: whereto they will not answear, till
e
states be come together. Astouching
that proposall, w
ch
I made unto yo
r
L. for
e
imploiment of
e forsaid forces, and as many more
unto them, as may make up
e nomber of five
or six thousand, for all this sommer season,
I was alwaies determined, to acquaint no man w
t
it, till
her
the states were agreed upon their
newe contribution, and till her Ma
tie
should com-
maund me, and write her letters to that effect.
Howbeit I have q
e
stioned heere w
t
divers by
way of discourse, whether it were not best for
e states, and for support of
e affaires of France,
and for
e Enemies annoiance in general,
at
6000 souldiers from hens, wel paied and still
fol.163v
renforced, should be imploied for this sommer in
e warres of France, and
at these contreis should
be kept by way of defense, considering
at their
strength is sufficient for it, and I doe not onely
finde none to oppose against it, but they doe all in
a maner desire it were effected. Wherupon I doe
not doubt, but if after a moneth (for by that
time w
t
e furthest, they will have passed their
consents, about their present contribution) her
Ma
ties
letters together w
t
e Kinges, shal be writ-
ten heere unto them, w
t
some good remonstrance,
and convenient instance, they will yelde very
willingly to all
at is requested.
Count Maurice
hath bin fourth w
t
certaine com-
panies of horse and foote to
e nomber of 3000
to surprise
Mastricht:
but hath missed of his
purpose: partly for
at his designe was not se-
cretly caried, whereby
e defendants were pre-
pared against his comming, and partly for
want of good order, for
at
e troupes had divers
guides, and were ledde in
e night by sundrie
waies, so as nether they approched
e towne at
one time together, nor gave
e assault in suffi-
cient nomber, nor in
e fittest places.
Whiche
is all
at I can signifie for mater
of
occurrence,
and therew
t
take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Marche 15 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
